questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue since he returned from visiting family in South Africa one week ago. The day after he returned, he had fever, chills, and diffuse joint pain for 3 days. His symptoms improved with acetaminophen. He was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.68°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.8 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
68 μm3



Red cell distribution width

14% (N = 13–15)


Hemoglobin A2

6% (N < 3.5)


A peripheral smear shows microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes, some of which have a darkly stained center and peripheral rim, separated by a pale ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is used to treat sickle cell anemia, which is also associated with target cells, and may manifest with fever, fatigue, and joint pain during a vaso-occlusive crisis. However, Hb electrophoresis would reveal elevated HbS, not an elevated HbA2. Additionally, sickle cells would be visible in a peripheral smear. This patient's recent fever, chills, and joint pains were likely due to a benign viral infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Albendazole is used to treat hookworm infections. Although this patient's travel history puts him at risk for an intestinal parasitic infection that can lead to iron deficiency anemia (as the hookworm ingests blood from the intestinal wall), he does not exhibit any signs of intestinal inflammation such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or diarrhea. Additionally, iron deficiency anemia would be unlikely to develop after only a week of infection. Lastly, although iron deficiency anemia can present as microcytic anemia, it is usually associated with elevated RDW, and an elevated HbA2 level and target cells would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Succimer is used to treat lead poisoning, which can cause microcytic anemia. However, the peripheral blood smear would show basophilic stippling and Hb electrophoresis would not show elevated HbA2.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with beta thalassemia minor are usually monitored without any additional treatment. The microcytic anemia caused by the condition is often confused with iron deficiency anemia. However, a normal RDW, elevated HbA2 level, and target cells indicate beta thalassemia minor as a much more likely cause (see “Interpretation of Hb-electrophoresis results for thalassemia” table).

This patient's history of fatigue, fever, and arthralgia is probably due to an acute viral infection. Episodic folic acid supplementation may be considered during acute infections.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Hypochromic erythrocytes with a dark central area, a pale ring surrounding the center, and a dark outer rim can be seen (dashed red circles on overlay). Due to this “bullseye” appearance on light microscopy, they are called target cells. On electron microscopy, they would appear bell-shaped (overlay illustration; visual axis in light microscopy depicted in red).

The finding of target cells is nonspecific and may indicate various hemoglobinopathies, such as thalassemia, liver disease, or asplenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine is used to treat sideroblastic anemia, which is also a possible cause of microcytic anemia and target cells. However, HbA2 would be normal, the RDW would be elevated, and the peripheral smear would also show ringed sideroblasts with prussian blue stain.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral iron supplementation is used to treat iron deficiency anemia, which also manifests as microcytic anemia. However, it is usually associated with elevated RDW, and an elevated HbA2 level and target cells would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features consistent with beta thalassemia minor: mild anemia, decreased MCV, target cells (RBCs with dark center and rim separated by a pale ring), a normal red cell distribution width (RDW), and increased HbA2 levels.

questions.text: A 5-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. The patient's Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He is 48.5 cm (19 in) in length and weighs 3080 g (6 lb 13 oz). He appears pale. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 167/min, and respirations are 56/min. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. No murmurs are heard. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.6 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 73 μm3. Genetic testing for hemoglobinopathies shows 3 missing alleles. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A low reticulocyte count with anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pathological jaundice is seen in congenital infections with bone marrow suppression (e.g., rubella, parvovirus B19), and neonatal leukemias, which are extremely rare. However, key features of these conditions are missing and normocytic anemia would be expected (not microcytic anemia). Patients with anemia due to thalassemia typically have a high reticulocyte count and RBC count because of increased production in response to hemolysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased spherocyte count is seen in patients with hereditary spherocytosis, which manifests with jaundice, splenomegaly, and pallor. However, patients typically develop normocytic anemia rather than microcytic anemia. Furthermore, thalassemias usually manifest with target cells and/or teardrop cells on peripheral blood smear, not spherocytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Schistocytes are seen in patients with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). Causes of MAHA with jaundice during the neonatal period include large hemangiomas (Kasabach-Merritt syndrome), congenital thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, and DIC due to sepsis. There is, however, no thrombocytopenia on the CBC to suggest any of these diagnoses. There is also no evidence of a hemangioma, petechiae/purpura, or risk factors associated with neonatal sepsis (e.g., preterm delivery, meconium-stained fluid, admission to a neonatal ICU).

D) INCORRECT:

Low serum ferritin is seen in patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA), which may occur in neonates as a result of decreased iron stores and increased iron requirement (due to rapid growth during early infancy). IDA would manifest as microcytic anemia but would not be expected at birth unless the mother had a severe iron deficiency as well. Jaundice, hepatomegaly, and missing alleles on genetic testing suggest thalassemia, in which serum ferritin levels are typically normal or even elevated (due to repeated transfusions).

E) CORRECT:

The production of alpha-globin is controlled by 2 genes (i.e., 4 alleles) on chromosome 16. The severity of alpha thalassemia is determined by the number of missing alleles. The absence of 3 alleles, as in this patient, indicates hemoglobin H disease (HbH disease), also referred to as alpha thalassemia intermedia (see “Overview of thalassemia” table). This condition is characterized by the presence of beta-globin tetramers, known as hemoglobin H (β4).

During the first weeks of life, newborns express fetal gamma-globin rather than beta-globin. In newborns with HbH disease, the relative deficiency of alpha-globin chains causes the fetal gamma-globin chains to tetramerize and form hemoglobin Barts (γ4); in unaffected newborns, hemoglobin F (α2,γ2) would be produced instead. Although hemoglobin Barts can arise in any type of alpha thalassemia (e.g., it accounts for 3–8% of the total hemoglobin in alpha thalassemia minor), newborns with HbH disease usually have 20–40% hemoglobin Barts at birth; hemoglobin Barts is occasionally used as a newborn screening parameter for these conditions. Four to six weeks after birth, beta-globin levels become sufficiently high for hemoglobin H to form, which can be seen on electrophoresis. Further expected findings in HbH disease include an elevated RBC count and reticulocyte count; these features can be used to distinguish between HbH disease and other types of anemia, such as iron deficiency anemia.

The presence of hemoglobin Barts is most pronounced in the absence of all 4 alleles (i.e., hemoglobin Barts disease), which typically leads to hydrops fetalis.

F) INCORRECT:

A compensatory increase of HbA2 (α2,δ2) and HbF (α2,γ2) due to decreased beta-globin chain synthesis is expected in patients with beta thalassemia. Severe forms of beta thalassemia (beta thalassemia major) manifest with pallor, microcytic anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and jaundice (due to hemolysis). However, the symptoms of beta thalassemia major usually appear after 4–6 months, when most of the beta-globin production occurs. Moreover, the production of beta-globin is controlled by a single gene (i.e., only 2 alleles). The absence of 3 alleles on genetic analysis and the onset of symptoms at birth suggest a diagnosis of alpha thalassemia. In alpha thalassemia, alpha-globin synthesis is affected and elevated HbA2 is therefore not expected.
questions.hint: A newborn with microcytic anemia, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and 3 missing alleles on genetic testing for hemoglobinopathies indicates a type of alpha thalassemia.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 11 weeks' gestation comes to her physician for a prenatal visit. She feels more fatigued than usual but has no other symptoms. She has no history of serious illness. She takes no medications. Her mother has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient recently immigrated from Cameroon. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.2 g/dL


Hematocrit
27.5%


Leukocyte count
6000/mm3



Platelet Count
180,000/mm3



MCV
74 μm3


MCH
23 pg/cell


Serum



 Na+

138 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 Cl-

100 mEq/L


 HCO3-

25 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
15 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Total Bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL


 Iron

67 U/L


 Ferritin

98 ng/mL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticardiolipin antibody is present in antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, which is strongly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. Because this patient has no features consistent with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (e.g., multiple first-trimester pregnancy loss), testing for anticardiolipin antibody is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravascular hemolysis causes lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and hemoglobin to be released into circulation. Free hemoglobin is bound by haptoglobin and excreted in urine, which causes the serum concentration of haptoglobin to decrease. While these tests may provide evidence of intravascular hemolysis, they are nonspecific and not the best for establishing the cause of this patient's microcytic anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Microcytic anemia in a pregnant woman warrants workup to determine the underlying cause and determine the appropriate treatment for reversing the anemia. Persistent anemia during pregnancy increases stress on the maternal heart, which must continue to provide adequate circulation, and this can lead to fetal hypoxemia. Reassurance would not suffice in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis is performed between 15–20 weeks' gestation to analyze fetal genetic material in the amniotic fluid. Although microcytic anemia in a mother of African-American descent should raise suspicion of maternal thalassemia, it is not an indication for genetic analysis of the fetus.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct Coombs test is used to diagnose autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which is a normocytic anemia with hyperbilirubinemia. Because this patient has microcytic anemia, a direct Coombs test is not indicated.

F) CORRECT:

A nulliparous woman with microcytic anemia should undergo workup to determine the underlying cause of her anemia. Because iron deficiency anemia (the most common form of microcytic anemia) has been ruled out and extreme microcytosis is present, this patient needs to be evaluated for thalassemia, for which the confirmatory test is hemoglobin electrophoresis. Thalassemias occur most commonly in individuals of Asian or African descent.
questions.hint: This patient presents with microcytic hypochromic anemia. The most common form of microcytic hypochromic anemia is iron deficiency anemia, which can be ruled out in this case given the normal serum iron and ferritin levels.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue and dizziness for the past 2 months. During this period, she has also had mild upper abdominal pain that is not related to food intake. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. She immigrated to the United States from Italy 10 years ago. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. There is no scleral icterus. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
62 μm3


Leukocyte count
7000/mm3



Platelet count
260,000/mm3



A peripheral blood smear shows target cells. The patient is started on iron supplementation. Three weeks later, her laboratory studies are unchanged. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Mutation in the δ-ALA synthase gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Absence of the glycosylphosphatidylinositol anchor, which is necessary for the attachment of complement inhibitor surface proteins like CD55 and CD59, results in destruction of erythrocytes by the complement system, as seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH can also manifest with symptoms of anemia and splenomegaly. However, this condition causes normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia, and usually also manifests with thrombocytopenia and/or leukopenia. In addition, this patient lacks other typical features of PNH, such as episodes of jaundice, red or dark urine, and arterial or venous thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ankyrin and spectrin are plasma membrane proteins. Defects in these proteins cause hereditary spherocytosis, a condition that manifests with symptoms of anemia and splenomegaly. However, this condition typically causes normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. In addition, hereditary spherocytosis results in the presence of spherocytes on peripheral blood smear, not target cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Ferrochelatase and ALA dehydratase are enzymes that catalyze steps in the heme biosynthesis pathway and can be inhibited by lead poisoning. Though lead poisoning can manifest with microcytic anemia, this patient lacks other characteristic symptoms of this condition, such as constipation, muscle weakness, paresthesias, and basophilic stippling on peripheral blood smear.

D) INCORRECT:

Myeloid stem cell destruction causes aplastic anemia, which can be idiopathic, inherited, or acquired. This condition typically results in normocytic or macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. In addition, patients with aplastic anemia typically develop recurrent hemorrhages (due to thrombocytopenia) and recurrent infections (due to leukopenia).

E) CORRECT:

The beta-globin chain is a subunit of hemoglobin. There are two beta-globin genes; point mutations in one or both of these genes can result in decreased production of beta-globin chain and cause beta thalassemia. Beta thalassemia primarily affects people from regions where malaria is endemic (e.g., the Mediterranean, parts of Africa and Asia) as thalassemia provides a certain level of resistance to malaria. The severity of disease corresponds to the amount of normal beta-globin chain production and ranges from asymptomatic microcytic anemia (beta thalassemia minor) to lifelong dependence on blood transfusion (beta thalassemia major). Because the underlying cause of anemia in patients with this condition is a defect of beta-globin gene synthesis (not iron deficiency), iron supplementation does not typically improve symptoms. A diagnosis of beta thalassemia can be confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis and/or DNA analysis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Hypochromic erythrocytes with a dark central area, a pale ring surrounding the center, and a dark outer rim can be seen (dashed red circles on overlay). Due to this “bullseye” appearance on light microscopy, they are called target cells. On electron microscopy, they would appear bell-shaped (overlay illustration; visual axis in light microscopy depicted in red).

The finding of target cells is nonspecific and may indicate various hemoglobinopathies, such as thalassemia, liver disease, or asplenia.

F) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the δ-ALA synthase gene can cause sideroblastic anemia, a rare condition that leads to microcytic anemia and splenomegaly. However, peripheral blood smear in patients with sideroblastic anemia shows basophilic stippling, not target cells.

G) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency results in impaired DNA synthesis and macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency, such as neurologic symptoms (e.g., ataxia, spasticity, and decreased proprioception and vibratory sensation due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord).
questions.hint: The most severe variant of this patient's condition manifests during childhood with hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal deformities (high forehead, prominent zygomatic bones, and maxilla) due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She has no particular health concerns. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
74 μm3


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
30% Hb/cell


Red cell distribution width
14% (N = 13–15)



Genetic analysis shows a point mutation in intron 1 of a gene on the short arm of chromosome 11. A process involving which of the following components is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transfer RNA (tRNA) are specialized RNA adaptors used during protein translation to help build the growing peptide from the mature mRNA template. An intronic mutation will affect transcription or post-transcriptional processing but not translation, since the introns are removed prior to translation.

B) INCORRECT:

MicroRNAs (miRNA) are small molecules that regulate post-transcriptional protein expression by binding to the 3' untranslated region of a target mRNA. Point mutations in the intron of the β-globin gene will not affect miRNA activity.

C) INCORRECT:

TATA-rich nucleotide sequences occur in the promoter region of genes. Beta-thalassemia can be caused by point mutations at the promoter site, which would impair transcription of hnRNA. However, the mutation in this patient is located within the gene on an intron, not at the promoter site; hnRNA will most likely be transcribed in this patient, but processing of hnRNA to mRNA will be affected.

D) INCORRECT:

Heat shock proteins (HSPs) are intracellular protein involved in facilitating and/or maintaining protein folding as well as preventing protein denaturing at high temperatures. The mutation in the intronic DNA occurring in beta-thalassemia traits would directly affect a transcriptional or post-transcriptional process, not a post-translational modification (e.g., protein folding).

E) INCORRECT:

H1 histone proteins are involved in the proper coiling of the DNA necessary for chromatin formation. Proper coiling of DNA regulates the degree of transcription occurring at a particular locus. However, the single point mutation in the intron of the β-globin gene is unlikely to influence H1 histone binding or chromatin structure, which is typically mediated by modifications (e.g., acetylation, methylation) on the histone proteins.

F) CORRECT:

Small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNP) are the subunits of spliceosomes, which are required for proper processing of pre-mRNA (hnRNA). Spliceosomes remove the introns from pre-mRNA through specific splicing sites encoded in introns (AG at the 3' end and GU at the 5' end). Mutations in the intronic splice site of the β-globin locus result in improper splicing, which leads to expression of abnormal β-globin.
Image Description:

Splicing is a posttranscriptional modification of a newly synthesized pre-mRNA molecule. Noncoding gene sequences (introns) are excised from the pre-mRNA molecule and the protein-coding regions (exons) are joined together.
The process involves two transesterification reactions: The first occurs between the 5′ splice site and the 2′ OH of the branch point (A). The second transesterification occurs between the 5′ splice site and 3′ splice site. The process is catalyzed by snRNPs (U1–U6), which together form the spliceosome. The excised intron is released in a lariat structure and the exons are ligated together.
questions.hint: This asymptomatic patient presents with a mild microcytic, hypochromic anemia, a normal red cell distribution width, and a point mutation in the first intron of a gene on the short arm of chromosome 11 (beta-globin locus). These findings are consistent with β-thalassemia minor.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with β-thalassemia major comes to the physician with a 1-week history of fatigue. She receives approximately 8 blood transfusions per year; her last transfusion was 1 month ago. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Her hemoglobin level is 6.5 mg/dL. Microscopic evaluation of a liver biopsy specimen in this patient would most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Macrophages with cytoplasmic granules that stain golden-yellow with hematoxylin
Cytoplasmic brown-pigmented granules that stain positive for S-100
Cytoplasmic pink-staining granules that stain positive with PAS

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing macrophages with yellow-brown, lipid-containing granules describes lipofuscin deposits, which accumulate with increasing age in several organs such as the heart and neurons. Pathologically increased deposition of lipofuscin is implicated in the pathogenesis of various diseases, including macular degeneration, neurocognitive disorders like Alzheimer disease, and various lysosomal storage diseases. However, it is not associated with iron overload.

B) CORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing macrophages with cytoplasmic granules that stain golden-yellow with hematoxylin describes hemosiderin deposits. These often occur in the setting of chronic iron overload, as seen in this patient. Recurrent blood transfusions stimulate increased hemolysis with subsequent phagocytosis of hemoglobin by macrophages, thereby promoting hemosiderin accumulation. In severe cases, secondary hemochromatosis eventually develops. This patient's biopsy sample would also stain brightly with Prussian blue, which identifies intracellular iron.

C) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing extracellular deposition of pink-staining proteins is characteristic of amyloid proteins, which can accumulate in the setting of localized or systemic amyloidosis. Amyloid proteins can best be visualized with congo-red stain and develop either in response to chronic inflammatory or infectious conditions or idiopathically as primary amyloidosis. However, neither thalassemia nor chronic transfusion therapy is associated with the development of secondary amyloidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing cytoplasmic brown-pigmented granules that stain positive for S-100 would be consistent with metastatic melanoma. However, because this patient does not have a history of suspicious skin lesions or previously diagnosed melanoma, metastatic melanoma is highly unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing cytoplasmic pink-staining granules that stain positive with PAS indicate deposition of excess sugars. This finding is typically observed in patients with glycogen storage diseases but not in those receiving chronic blood transfusions.
questions.hint: Individuals requiring recurrent blood transfusions are susceptible to an iron overload state.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of generalized weakness and difficulty walking for the past month. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 6.6 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 70 μm3, platelet count of 150,000/mm3, and serum total bilirubin concentration of 2 mg/dl. An MRI of the spine shows low signal intensity in all vertebral bodies and a small epidural mass compressing the spinal canal at the level of L1. A CT scan of the head shows osteopenia with widening of the diploic spaces in the skull. A biopsy of the epidural mass shows erythroid colonies with an abundance of megakaryocytes and myeloid cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary spherocytosis can cause anemia and hyperbilirubinemia as a result of hemolysis. However, in hereditary spherocytosis, extramedullary hematopoiesis is rare, and patients usually develop normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

G6PD deficiency can cause anemia and hyperbilirubinemia as a result of hemolysis, but only after exposure to significant oxidative stress (e.g., infection, consumption of fava beans). Furthermore, in G6PD deficiency, extramedullary hematopoiesis is rare, and patients usually develop normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Aplastic anemia manifests with pancytopenia and normocytic anemia, whereas this patient presents with a normal platelet count and microcytic anemia. Moreover, aplastic anemia would not be associated with hyperbilirubinemia and it does not lead to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Lead poisoning can cause microcytic anemia as well as mild hyperbilirubinemia due to hemolysis. However, this patient does not have the typical clinical manifestations of lead poisoning (e.g., intestinal colic, anorexia, constipation, encephalopathy). Furthermore, lead poisoning does not cause extramedullary hematopoiesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma (MM) can cause anemia and masses in the soft tissue (extramedullary plasmacytoma) or bone. However, the anemia associated with MM is normocytic or macrocytic, not microcytic, and a biopsy of such a mass would show ≥ 10% clonal plasma cells, not erythroid colonies. Moreover, imaging of the skull would reveal focal lytic lesions with a punched-out appearance, not widening of the diploic spaces. Finally, multiple myeloma is typically diagnosed in adults; it is extremely rare in children.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

F) CORRECT:

In patients with beta thalassemia, defective hemoglobin chain synthesis results in ineffective hematopoiesis and subsequent chronic anemia. In a state of severe chronic anemia, extramedullary hematopoiesis often occurs as a compensatory mechanism. Extramedullary hematopoiesis most commonly involves the paravertebral areas, as seen in this patient, followed by the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes.

While extramedullary hematopoiesis in the spleen and liver is physiological during fetal development, it is always pathological after birth.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a child with beta thalassemia

Expansion of the diploic space with thickening of the trabeculae (example indicated by green overlay) is the result of extramedullary hematopoiesis. The hair-on-end appearance (examples indicated by red lines) produced can also be seen in other chronic hemolytic anemias.
questions.hint: The presence of erythroid colonies in the epidural space on biopsy and widening of the diploic spaces in the skull on imaging indicate extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of mild fatigue and weakness. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 74 μm3. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows 10% HbA2 (N < 3.5). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Beta thalassemia minor, which is caused by mutations in one of the two alleles coding for β-globin chains, manifests as mild microcytic anemia with decreased HbA (ααββ) and compensatory increase of HbA2 (ααδδ) and HbF (ααγγ). Unlike beta thalassemia major (two deficient alleles), beta thalassemia minor usually manifests later in life, causes milder anemia, and rarely causes splenomegaly, all of which are consistent with this patient's clinical presentation. See “Interpretation of Hb-electrophoresis results for thalassemia” table.

Beta thalassemia minor is sometimes mistaken for iron deficiency anemia, but it does not respond to iron supplementation. While there is usually no need for treatment, episodic folic acid supplementation may be indicated in certain conditions (e.g., during pregnancy, acute infections).

B) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin Barts disease, the most severe type of alpha thalassemia, is caused by a deletion of all 4 α-globin gene loci and results in excessive production of pathologic γ-globin tetramer. It causes hydrops fetalis and leads to intrauterine fetal demise or death shortly after birth.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha thalassemia minima, the most benign type of alpha thalassemia, is caused by a deletion of 1 out of 4 α-globin gene loci. It manifests with normal HbA2, unlike in this patient. Moreover, patients with alpha thalassemia minima are classically asymptomatic.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin H disease, a severe type of alpha thalassemia, is caused by a deletion of 3 out of 4 α-globin gene loci and results in excessive production of pathologically altered HbH. It usually manifests in neonates with mild to moderate anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and jaundice. While it causes decreased HbA, which would be expected in this patient, it is also associated with decreased HbA2.

E) INCORRECT:

Sickle cell trait manifests in patients with a mutation in only one of the two β-globin alleles. While sickle cell trait manifests with decreased HbA, which is expected in this patient, it would be also associated with elevated HbAS. In addition, it causes a normocytic (not a microcytic) anemia and does not manifest with the elevated HbA2 seen in this patient.
questions.hint: In addition to the significant elevation in HbA2, this patient's hemoglobin electrophoresis would most likely show a decreased HbA concentration and increased HbF concentration.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman gives birth to a stillborn male fetus at 30 weeks' gestation. The patient received no prenatal care. Her pregnancy had been uncomplicated. She has no history of serious medical illness. She has a 3-year-old daughter who is healthy. The patient and her family emigrated from the Philippines to the United States 1 year ago. Examination of the stillborn fetus shows pale skin and generalized edema. There are no visible malformations. At autopsy, examination shows ascites, hepatosplenomegaly, and pericardial and pleural effusions; the placenta appears abnormally enlarged. Laboratory studies obtained from the mother show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Erythrocyte count
5.5 million/mm3


Mean corpuscular volume
69 μm3


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
19 pg/cell


Red cell distribution width
13.4% (N = 13%–15%)


Leukocyte count
9300/mm3



Platelet count
240,000/mm3



Serum



Ferritin
54 ng/mL


Maternal blood group
A, Rh-positive


Which of the following is the most likely cause of stillbirth in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain congenital infections, such as parvovirus B19, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, and syphilis, can cause nonimmune hydrops fetalis. This patient received no prenatal care, which includes screening for some infections (e.g., syphilis), and parvovirus B19 infection can cause maternal anemia as a result of pure red cell aplasia (PRCA). However, PRCA causes normocytic, normochromic anemia with a decreased erythrocyte count, and nonimmune hydrops fetalis due to a congenital infection is typically also associated with other fetal findings such as intracranial, hepatic, and/or pericardial calcifications, microcephaly/macrocephaly, chorioretinitis, and evidence of extramedullary erythropoiesis (e.g., blueberry muffin rash).

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal alloimmunization typically occurs in the first pregnancy with a Rhesus (Rh) incompatibility between the mother and fetus and causes immune hydrops fetalis in subsequent pregnancies. However, this disease only occurs when the mother is Rh-negative, and it causes fetal anemia (hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn) rather than maternal anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Fetomaternal bleeding is the loss of fetal blood into maternal circulation; massive fetomaternal bleeding can cause nonimmune hydrops fetalis in an otherwise uncomplicated pregnancy. However, fetomaternal bleeding would not result in anemia in the mother.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal aneuploidy (e.g., monosomy X, trisomy 21, trisomy 18, trisomy 13) can cause nonimmune hydrops fetalis (NIHF). However, patients with NIHF due to fetal aneuploidy typically have the dysmorphic features associated with these aneuploidies. Moreover, fetal aneuploidy does not result in maternal anemia.

E) CORRECT:

In alpha thalassemia major, all four alleles coding for the α-globin chains are absent, resulting in fetal anemia. In anemia, only hemoglobin Bart (Hb Bart) is produced, which consists of four γ-chains. Hb Bart delivers negligible amounts of oxygen to peripheral tissue because the γ-chains have a high affinity for oxygen. This condition, therefore, causes severe fetal hypoxia, which leads to high-output heart failure and consequently nonimmune hydrops fetalis. Alpha thalassemia major results in death in utero or shortly after birth. This condition most commonly occurs in individuals of Asian or African descent and has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. This patient's mother (and father) have alpha thalassemia minor, which causes microcytic, hypochromic anemia with normal or increased ferritin levels, a normal red cell distribution width, and a Mentzer index < 13.
questions.hint: This stillborn fetus has features of hydrops fetalis (hepatosplenomegaly, generalized edema, ascites, pericardial and pleural effusions), which can also manifest with an enlarged (hydropic) placenta. Genetic testing of the stillborn fetus would most likely show four missing alpha globin alleles.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of nausea and fatigue. She has not had fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago. Her medical history is remarkable for α-thalassemia minor. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 121/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.5 g/dL


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
22 pg/cell


Mean corpuscular volume
75/mm3



Erythrocyte count
3.8 million/mm3



Red cell distribution width
14% (N = 13%–15%)


Serum



Ferritin
98 ng/mL


Bilirubin, total
1.1 mg/dL


Direct
0.2 mg/dL


Lactate dehydrogenase
200 U/L


β-hCG
positive


Genetic testing of the patient's partner shows two defective alleles in the α-globin gene. The physician counsels the patient on her condition and the risks of pregnancy. The patient states that she wants to continue the pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this point?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding should be discouraged in certain fetal (e.g., galactosemia) and maternal conditions (e.g., HIV infection in resource-rich settings). However, with the exception of those who are taking iron-chelating agents, there are no contraindications to breastfeeding in patients with thalassemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Iron chelating agents, such as deferasirox, are often used to treat thalassemia and may help patients achieve spontaneous pregnancy. However, iron chelating agents are typically only used in patients who require blood transfusion (i.e. those with α-thalassemia major or α-thalassemia intermedia) and are therefore at risk of iron overload. Moreover, deferasirox should be discontinued 3 months before conception because its safety during pregnancy has not been established.

C) INCORRECT:

Fetal screening for thalassemia is necessary in pregnant patients with thalassemia who have partners with confirmed thalassemia trait. However, amniocentesis is not the preferred screening test before 15 weeks' gestation because of the risk of complications, such as premature rupture of the membranes, and therefore should not be performed in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

If both parents have thalassemia trait, fetal testing for thalassemia should be performed using chorionic villus sampling at 10–13 weeks' gestation or via amniocentesis from 15 weeks' gestation to determine the fetus's carrier status. Because of the risk of fetal (e.g., growth restriction, prematurity) and maternal (e.g., cardiac failure, thrombosis, diabetes mellitus) complications, close antenatal and perinatal monitoring and management are warranted if either the mother or the fetus has thalassemia. For example, early diagnosis of hemoglobin Bart disease is essential because serial intrauterine transfusions may be necessary to ensure adequate oxygen delivery to fetal tissues.

Many patients with thalassemia are infertile (due to transfusional hemosiderosis and subsequent hypogonadotropic hypogonadism) and require assisted reproductive technology to achieve pregnancy. Spontaneous fertility may occur in patients with mild forms of thalassemia and those who have successfully undergone iron chelation therapy and blood transfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

If both partners have thalassemia major, alternatives to pregnancy, such as adoption and artificial insemination with donor sperm should be considered. Although this couple's genetic profile increases the risk that their child will inherit mutated α-globin alleles, termination of the pregnancy is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient and her partner both have alpha thalassemia trait. Pregnancies in patients with thalassemia should be planned, as they are considered high-risk for both the mother and fetus.

skull x-ray: shown
MRI of the spine: low signal intensity in all vertebral bodies; small epidural mass compressing the spinal canal at the level of L1
histopathology of a biopsy sample from the epidural mass: erythroid colonies with an abundance of megakaryocytes and myeloid cells



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Microcytic hypochromic anemia, indirect hyperbilirubinemia due to peripheral hemolysis, a Mentzer index < 13, and extramedullary hematopoiesis indicate beta thalassemia. Beta thalassemia is caused by defective hemoglobin chain synthesis, which leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and subsequent chronic anemia. Extramedullary hematopoiesis often occurs as a compensatory mechanism in patients with chronic anemia and commonly involves the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes and can also affect the bones (e.g., skull) and paravertebral areas, causing spinal cord compression, which can lead to lower extremity weakness, hyperreflexia, and decreased sensation below the level of compression. Extramedullary hematopoiesis in the spleen and liver is physiological during fetal development but is always pathological after birth.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma (MM) can cause anemia and masses in the soft tissue (extramedullary plasmacytoma) or bone. However, MM is associated with normocytic or macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia, and histopathology of a biopsy sample would show ≥ 10% clonal plasma cells rather than erythroid colonies. Moreover, imaging of the skull would reveal focal lytic lesions with a punched-out appearance, not widening of the diploic spaces. Also, MM is extremely rare in children.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Lead poisoning can cause microcytic anemia and mild hyperbilirubinemia as a result of hemolysis. However, typical features such as intestinal colic, anorexia, constipation, and encephalopathy would also be expected. Furthermore, lead poisoning does not cause extramedullary hematopoiesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) can develop secondary to a myelodysplastic syndrome and can manifest with extramedullary hematopoiesis and splenomegaly. However, AML also usually manifests with pancytopenia as a result of uncontrolled proliferation of abnormal myeloid cells in the bone marrow. Also, AML is extremely rare in children.

E) INCORRECT:

Aplastic anemia manifests with pancytopenia including normocytic anemia, whereas this patient has a normal platelet and WBC count and microcytic anemia. Moreover, aplastic anemia does not result in hyperbilirubinemia or extramedullary hematopoiesis.

F) INCORRECT:

Langerhans cell histiocytosis can cause splenomegaly and bone marrow infiltration. However, extramedullary hematopoiesis is rare in Langerhans cell histiocytosis, and histopathology of a biopsy sample would typically reveal polygonal cells with coffee bean-shaped nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm (i.e., Langerhans cell proliferation) rather than erythroid colonies with an abundance of megakaryocytes and myeloid cells.
questions.hint: Splenomegaly, biopsy-confirmed erythroid colonies in the epidural space, and widening of the diploic spaces in the skull on x-ray indicate extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man returns for follow-up after treatment for deep-vein thrombosis. The deep-vein thrombosis was complicated by a nonocclusive pulmonary embolus in the segmental branches of the left lower lobe and lingula, as seen on a CT angiogram of his thorax. He has no history of recent trauma or long-distance travel, and he does not smoke or use illicit drugs.
The patient was treated with therapeutic low-molecular-weight heparin and transitioned to warfarin 5 mg daily by mouth. (Rivaroxaban was initially recommended, but there were cost concerns.) His international normalized ratio is 2.3, within the target range of 2.0 to 3.0.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range

10,600
4500–11,000

8.6
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
586,000
150,000–350,000

Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
1.2

Creatinine (mg/dL)

Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Factor V Leiden mutation can predispose people to thromboses but is not associated with microcytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome can predispose people to thromboses but is not associated with microcytic anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Beta-thalassemia is a congenital hemolytic anemia caused by reduced or absent synthesis of the beta chains of hemoglobin. Phenotypes vary considerably; these include the asymptomatic carrier state (heterozygous for mutation in beta-chain gene; also known as beta-thalassemia minor); moderate anemia that may require intermittent blood transfusions (beta-thalassemia intermedia); and severe, transfusion-dependent anemia (beta-thalassemia major). Survival has been shown to improve significantly with regular blood transfusions and strict adherence to iron-chelation therapy.

Patients with beta-thalassemia have uniformly microcytic erythrocytes. Thrombocytosis is often seen in these patients because of increased drive on the marrow from erythropoietin. In patients with beta-thalassemia who have had splenectomy, platelet counts are typically elevated. Although iron deficiency can also lead to microcytosis and is often associated with an elevated platelet count, the red-cell distribution width is typically elevated in that setting, whereas it is almost always normal in thalassemia.

Patients with beta-thalassemia intermedia are at high risk for developing venous thromboembolism. Those who have had a splenectomy are at even higher risk. Beta-thalassemia leads to abnormal erythrocytes that express procoagulant phospholipids, activated clotting factors, and activated platelets, all of which predispose patients to thrombosis. Hypercoagulability risk factors in patients with beta-thalassemia include older age, female sex, iron overload, and prior splenectomy.

Key learning point: Patients with beta-thalassemia intermedia are at increased risk for developing venous thromboembolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease leads to bleeding complications, not thromboses.

E) INCORRECT:

Factor VIII inhibitor formation leads to bleeding complications, not thromboses.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old gravida 0, para 0 woman born in El Salvador presents with fatigue. She has no known medical history and takes no medications. She has had regular menses since age 12 and average blood loss with each cycle. Her vital signs and physical examination are normal.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7500
4500–11,000



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.3
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
25
36–46

65
80–100


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
5,600,000
4,000,000–5,200,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
250,000
150,000–350,000



Ferritin (ng/mL)
60
30–300


Red-cell distribution width (%)
13.8
11.5–14.5


Her peripheral-blood smear shows normal-appearing leukocytes and platelets with microcytic, hypochromic red cells and some target cells.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Iron level and total iron-binding capacity

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Microcytic anemias are seen in conditions in which heme or globin synthesis is impaired, including iron deficiency, lead poisoning, thalassemia, and, rarely, inflammation. The serum ferritin level is an indicator of cellular iron stores. The red-cell distribution width is normal in most patients with thalassemia but elevated in the other major cause of microcytic anemia, iron deficiency. The initial evaluation for the thalassemias is through hemoglobin electrophoresis or high-performance liquid chromatography, identifying variants associated with beta-thalassemia.

Key learning point: The diagnosis most suggested by microcytic anemia in a patient with a normal red-cell distribution width and normal iron stores is either alpha-thalassemia or beta-thalassemia.

B) INCORRECT:

An erythrocyte sedimentation rate is a nonspecific marker of inflammation and is unlikely to be diagnostically helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

A bone-marrow biopsy is helpful in evaluating for hematologic neoplasms or other causes of anemia, but this clinical scenario is highly suggestive of thalassemia; hemoglobin electrophoresis is the best next step.

D) INCORRECT:

Checking vitamin B12 and folate levels is not helpful. Deficiencies of those nutrients lead to a macrocytic anemia, although concurrent conditions associated with microcytic or normocytic anemias can decrease the mean corpuscular volume.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron level and total iron-binding capacity are unlikely to be informative in a patient with a normal ferritin level who has no features of an inflammatory disease.

questions.text:
A healthy 35-year-old woman presents to discuss an abnormal complete blood count ordered by her gynecologist.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.8
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
35.6
36.0–46.0


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
64
80–100


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
5,500,000
4,000,000–5,200,000


Red-cell distribution width (%)
14
11.5–14.5


Her platelet and leukocyte counts are normal.
She recalls being told about a mild anemia when she was a teenager. She is not sure whether her parents or siblings have ever been diagnosed with an abnormal complete blood count. Her menstrual periods are regular and not heavy.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mild anemia of chronic disease is not generally associated with such a low MCV. Moreover, this patient has no diagnosed chronic disease or systemic symptoms to suggest a chronic illness.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency manifests with acute hemolytic anemia after exposure to triggering substances (foods or medications) but would be expected to have normal red-cell indices between hemolytic episodes, including normal MCV values.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin C trait is associated with a normal or only mildly decreased MCV.

D) CORRECT:

Beta-thalassemia trait is characterized by a very low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), often in the 60s μm3. The hemoglobin and hematocrit are usually in the lower part of the normal range or only mildly reduced. The erythrocyte count is routinely noted on most automated complete blood count reports, but clinicians do not usually look at it. However, the erythrocyte count can provide useful information, as it is often high (>5 million per mm3) in patients with beta-thalassemia trait but low in those with iron deficiency.

Various indices have been evaluated to help distinguish iron-deficiency anemia from beta-thalassemia trait, such as the Mentzer index. This score is calculated by dividing the MCV by the erythrocyte count; a value below 13% suggests beta-thalassemia trait. In addition, the red-cell distribution width is usually normal in beta-thalassemia trait but increased (>14%) in iron deficiency. Patients with beta-thalassemia trait have an elevated hemoglobin A2 on hemoglobin electrophoresis.

Alpha-thalassemia trait can manifest with red-cell indices similar to those of beta-thalassemia trait and is another consideration in this case. Hemoglobin electrophoresis would be able to differentiate these conditions; it would be normal in alpha-thalassemia, and DNA analysis is therefore required to confirm the diagnosis.

Patients with both thalassemia trait and iron deficiency may be difficult to identify from simple inspection of the parameters reported with the complete blood count.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an asymptomatic person with a mean corpuscular volume in the 60s but a normal or near-normal hemoglobin level is beta-thalassemia trait (also known as beta-thalassemia minor) or alpha-thalassemia trait.

E) INCORRECT:

Unlike a patient with a near-normal hemoglobin level, a patient with iron deficiency is usually severely anemic by the time the MCV has reached the mid- to low 60s. Moreover, the erythrocyte count is low in iron deficiency.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents for her first medical visit after immigrating to the United States. She has generally been healthy and takes no medications. She reached menarche at age 13 and has normal menses, with moderate flow that lasts 5 days.
Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 95 beats per minute. Her physical examination is normal.
Laboratory analysis is performed as part of screening for a new immigrant. All results are normal with the exception of some elements of the complete blood count:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9000

12.0–16.0

350,000
150,000–350,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
71
80–100


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
5,900,000
4,000,000–5,200,000


Red-cell distribution width (%)
11.5
11.5–14.5


Microcytosis, hypochromasia, and target cells are noted on the blood smear.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s complete blood count reveals microcytic anemia (low hematocrit associated with low mean corpuscular volume [MCV]), and the blood smear shows small pale cells (microcytosis with hypochromasia) with some target cells. The main types of microcytic anemia are iron-deficiency anemia, thalassemia, sideroblastic anemia, and anemia of inflammation.

Beta-thalassemia trait (also known as beta-thalassemia minor) and iron deficiency are the two most common microcytic anemias, and the red-cell distribution width (RDW) and Mentzer index (mean corpuscular volume/erythrocyte count) can be used to help distinguish between them. The combination of a normal RDW and a Mentzer index <13 (as seen in this case) is consistent with beta- or alpha-thalassemia trait, whereas a high RDW and a Mentzer index >13 is more consistent with iron-deficiency anemia. Although the Mentzer index can be used to screen for thalassemia, it is not diagnostic.

In a patient with suspected thalassemia, diagnosis can be confirmed via hemoglobin electrophoresis. Patients with alpha-thalassemia trait will have normal findings on electrophoresis, whereas those with beta-thalassemia trait will have elevated hemoglobin A2 related to increased production of delta chains. This patient has a relatively low hemoglobin count and is therefore more likely to have beta-thalassemia trait than alpha-thalassemia trait.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who has microcytic anemia with a normal red-cell distribution width is beta-thalassemia trait.

B) INCORRECT:

Haptoglobin testing is appropriate for suspected hemolytic anemia, but this patient has no history — or evidence on blood smear — to suggest hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of vitamin B12 levels is helpful in patients with macrocytic anemia and an elevated MCV, which are associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, but this patient has microcytic anemia with a low MCV.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of ferritin levels is appropriate for suspected iron-deficiency anemia, and lead testing can be considered if lead poisoning is thought to be the cause of the iron-deficiency anemia. However, this patient's RDW and Mentzer index are more consistent with thalassemia than iron-deficiency anemia. Sideroblastic anemia is a consequence of problems with heme synthesis and is typically associated with a high RDW.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of ferritin levels is appropriate for suspected iron-deficiency anemia, and lead testing can be considered if lead poisoning is thought to be the cause of the iron-deficiency anemia. However, this patient's RDW and Mentzer index are more consistent with thalassemia than iron-deficiency anemia. Sideroblastic anemia is a consequence of problems with heme synthesis and is typically associated with a high RDW.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old boy who was born full term is brought in for evaluation. Review of his newborn screening for hemoglobinopathies reveals only hemoglobin F.
Which one of the following next steps is best for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A peripheral blood smear can yield significant findings for numerous diagnoses but is not the diagnostic test of choice for a thalassemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic penicillin would be appropriate if the newborn screening showed a hemoglobin pattern such as FS that raised concern for hemoglobin SS disease. In these cases, penicillin is used to reduce the risk of infection with encapsulated bacteria related to impaired splenic function.

C) CORRECT:

The presence of hemoglobin F without hemoglobin A on newborn screening raises suspicion for possible beta-thalassemia major and warrants immediate referral to a pediatric hematologist. In beta-thalassemia, gene mutations lead to reduced (or no) production of beta-globin chains, resulting in an abnormal increase in the ratio of alpha to beta chains; this, in turn, causes ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolytic anemia. Infants with beta-thalassemia are often not symptomatic until 4 to 6 months of age, when they attempt to transition from complete reliance on hemoglobin F (which is not made of beta chains) to hemoglobin A (which does require beta chains). Symptoms can be very heterogeneous during this transition but may include those consistent with hemolysis, such as dark urine and jaundice, and those consistent with an evolving anemia, such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. The definitive test for beta-thalassemia is a globin gene test.

Key learning point: When newborn screening for hemoglobinopathies reveals only hemoglobin F, the most appropriate next step is globin gene testing.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine pediatric care would be appropriate if the patient had a normal newborn screening result of hemoglobin FA. However, this patient’s result shows only hemoglobin F and therefore warrants further evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone-marrow aspiration would be indicated if there were concern for a process in the bone marrow that was either infiltrative or aplastic in nature. However, this patient is not reported to have any abnormalities of his hematologic parameters, and a bone-marrow evaluation is not warranted as part of a newborn screen or beta-thalassemia workup.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman returns for follow-up after treatment for deep-vein thrombosis. The deep-vein thrombosis was complicated by a nonocclusive pulmonary embolus in the segmental branches of the left lower lobe and lingula, as seen on a CT angiogram of her thorax. She has no history of recent trauma or long-distance travel, does not smoke or use illicit drugs, and is not taking oral contraceptives.
She was treated with therapeutic low-molecular-weight heparin and transitioned to rivaroxaban 10 mg daily by mouth.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
10,600
4500 - 11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.6
13.5 - 17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
586,000
150,000 - 350,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
66
